body: This seems great. Can it show nested runs and let the user expand those too (runs with a parent run ID)?

Hello,
Here is the first PR, it's for whitelisting columns, I put it on our fork first https://github.com/criteo-forks/mlflow/pull/38 ; you can already have a look, I'll put it in this repo next.
It's an important part because it allows the UI to be fast, which is crucial.

For the ui : 
I did not implement nested run yet, I can add it but I have a few questions : 
* what is the use case of this feature : why wouldn't users compare runs between "master runs" ?
* how should it work UX wise ? for example what should happen in kind of sorting, which runs get displayed first ? (current behavior is to sort regardless of nesting which is not intuitive)

The reason why I chose react table is because it already implements : 
* ordering by clicking on the column names (and even multiple column ordering)
* filtering on top of each columns
* pagination (page count, page numbering, selection of numbers of runs by page)
* calling the API when doing ordering, filtering, ...
Wheras I would have to reimplement all of this if using ReactVirtualized

So I think it has more features out of the box.

I will soon publish a PR for the ui, I hope that will make things clearer.
That's the second pull request, to add the total run count in backend https://github.com/criteo-forks/mlflow/pull/43 ; important to implement pagination in UI. It's also useful in general

One of the concerns with adding "run count" as a part of `SearchRuns` API response is that it dictates how the backend would implement pagination and makes it necessary for all backend implementations to support that. For instance the backend developers would be required to:
1. Either load all results from search query and then apply pagination filter to extract qualifying page of results
2. Do a dual query on backend one for counts (without pagination filters) and apply entire filter including pagination to extract necessary result. 

Support this is easier when doing limit and offset style of pagination but significantly harder when implementing cursor based tokens for pagination.

ref: [RFC for pagination](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Ygti9oyMbi4DJNbaM0D49nNIKb8BLXwGYQ7WmrOKJ3s/edit?usp=sharing)

I don't really understand.
Let me describe how it works here :
1. Client (ui or other) ask search runs for runs for some experiments, some
filter, some ordering, some offset (== page token which is just an encoding
of that offset), and some limit
2. Backend answers with : the total number of runs for these filters (minus
the limiting), *and* the runs for these filters and that limiting
3. The client then knows how many pages there are with that limiting and
can query again by increasing the offset to get an other page if needed

That's what I implemented in the backend and front.

Do you see any issue with that ?

On Tue, Nov 19, 2019, 05:16 Mani Parkhe <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> One of the concerns with adding "run count" with SearchRuns API is that
> it dictates how the backend would implement pagination. For instance the
> backend users would be required to
>
>    1. Either load all results from search query and then apply pagination
>    filter to extract qualifying page of results
>    2. Do a dual query on backend one for counts (without pagination
>    filters) and apply entire filter including pagination to extract necessary
>    result.
>
> This is easier when doing limit and offset style of pagination but
> significantly harder when implementing cursor based tokens for pagination.
>
> ref: RFC for pagination
> <https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Ygti9oyMbi4DJNbaM0D49nNIKb8BLXwGYQ7WmrOKJ3s/edit?usp=sharing>

Third pull request about being able to list all columns for a series of experiment https://github.com/criteo-forks/mlflow/pull/46

Hi @rom1504: Yes. The concern is with changing the API--specifically adding a separate `total_run_count` field in `SearchRuns.Response`. I am not sure how you intend on building the UI component described here and if that will **require** returned response to have this `total_run_count` value. Lemme clarify.

I am not sure if got a chance to look through the document I attached with my previous comment. We have deliberately tried to keep the token response as a generic string rather than a structured field. This gives the backend and frontend to have an opaque implementation for pagination. For instance, current open source pagination is an offset and limit based implementation -- where `offset` is returned in the json string. Another backend may choose to have a more detailed [cursor based approach](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Ygti9oyMbi4DJNbaM0D49nNIKb8BLXwGYQ7WmrOKJ3s/edit?usp=sharing#heading=h.76z02dr2xfy6) for implementing pagination. In the case of the latter, it may be difficult to know what is the exact # of runs that qualify the original search criteria (depending on how the backend is implemented). As I mentioned, the original design for `SearchRuns` with pagination API was such that it was open to any implementation of UI and backend.

I fact #2059 achieves this for SQL backend by pushing pagination down to SQL layer for efficiencies and total # of runs is no longer available. To get this additional information, it would be necessary to do an additional `COUNT` query with the same filter and no pagination to achieve total row count.

One way of doing this would be 
1. Leave it to individual backend developers if they want to add total run count. If so, the token can have an optional `"total_run_count"` field. Add this to the dictionary before encoding the token. Some backends like `FileStore` will be able to implement that while `SqlAlchemyStore` and `RestStore` may choose to not implement that.
2. UI: add an optional component for optional component for `total_run_count` field. If present it will show the field else will skip "of ..." in the display. Before implementing UI components please have @Zangr and @gioa approve design for UI.

Another note: Other MLflow developers that have created their own backend and UI implementations conformant to MLflow API have used `plugin` implementation to inject backend implementation.

Ok let me answer your concerns.

> I fact #2059 achieves this for SQL backend by pushing pagination down to SQL layer for efficiencies and total # of runs is no longer available. To get this additional information, it would be necessary to do an additional COUNT query with the same filter and no pagination to achieve total row count.

yes this is what I implemented there https://github.com/criteo-forks/mlflow/pull/43/files#diff-c56e37254d6acf031af8cf7d293c3622L663 (which is pretty simple and fast as you can see)

> Leave it to individual backend developers if they want to add total run count. If so, the token can have an optional "total_run_count" field. Add this to the dictionary before encoding the token. Some backends like FileStore will be able to implement that while SqlAlchemyStore and RestStore may choose to not implement that.

Sure I can make it optional and put the total run count return in the token if you prefer

About the ui, you can see on the first post the number of pages displayed, to be able to display that it's necessary to have the total number of runs for this filter.
I'm not sure how one could make an intuitive ui without that number of pages/runs.

After some more thought I have another proposal : what about adding a new endpoint that will return that number of runs and take the same filtering option as search runs ?
It would also serve my purpose without changing anything about search runs API

> Third pull request about being able to list all columns for a series of experiment [criteo-forks#46](https://github.com/criteo-forks/mlflow/pull/46)

I took a look at the PR. It is an interesting idea, but I wonder what is the use case for fetching column names. Depending on the # of runs in list of requested experiments this column list might be very large. Some of the experiments we have seen have 100K+ runs and collecting **all** the distinct column names for metrics, params, attributes, and tags for qualifying experiments could be prohibitively expensive. Especially, if the runs use different ML algorithms records lots of unique params and metrics, these lists could be extremely large. This also adds new API surface that would need to be implemented in all backends.

What is the use case for knowing **all** metric, param, tag, and attribute keys for all runs in an experiment or set of experiments. Have you considered other design choices for this--for instance one of the options for the UI shown in the picture above, could be for these column lists be dynamically deduced in the UI from the data in runs returned, rather than adding a whole new API. With pagination, you will only have a subset of column names which can be reduced in the UI and kept in cache (which you might have to anyways if using a different API). As new pages are pulled from backend, this cache could be kept active.

As a reminder: before implementing UI components please have @Zangr and @gioa approve design for UI.
